verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying,
verses.comment: This sets the time as one year after the Exodus.

verses.text: “Let the people of Israel keep the Passover at its appointed time.
verses.comment: Passover commanded on its proper date.

verses.text: On the fourteenth day of this month, at twilight, you shall keep it at its appointed time. According to all its statutes and all its regulations, you shall keep it.”
verses.comment: Specifies regulations and timing.

verses.text: So Moses told the people of Israel to keep the Passover.
verses.comment: Moses relays the command.

verses.text: And they kept the Passover in the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, at twilight, in the wilderness of Sinai. Everything was done just as the LORD commanded Moses.
verses.comment: Israel complies with the command exactly.

verses.text: But there were some men who were unclean because of a dead body, so they could not keep the Passover on that day. So they came before Moses and Aaron on that day.
verses.comment: Ritual uncleanness prevented participation.

verses.text: And those men said to him, “We are unclean because of a dead body. Why should we be kept from bringing the LORD’s offering at its appointed time among the people of Israel?”
verses.comment: The men ask about exclusion from Passover.

verses.text: Moses said to them, “Wait, and I will hear what the LORD will command concerning you.”
verses.comment: Moses seeks direction from God.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God responds with an answer.

verses.text: “Speak to the people of Israel, saying, ‘If any one of you or your descendants is unclean because of a dead body, or is far away on a journey, he may still keep the Passover to the LORD.
verses.comment: Provisions for those unclean or far away.

verses.text: In the second month, on the fourteenth day at twilight, they shall keep it. They shall eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
verses.comment: A second Passover provision for the ritually unclean or travelers.

verses.text: They shall not leave any of it until morning, nor break any of its bones; according to all the statutes of the Passover they shall keep it.
verses.comment: Rules for Passover lamb apply to second Passover.

verses.text: But if a man is clean and is not on a journey and still fails to keep the Passover, that person shall be cut off from his people, because he did not bring the LORD’s offering at its appointed time; that man shall bear his sin.
verses.comment: Deliberate neglect brings severe consequence.

verses.text: And if a foreigner lives among you and would keep the Passover to the LORD, he must do it according to the statute of the Passover, and according to its regulation. You shall have one statute, for both the foreigner and the native of the land.”
verses.comment: Equality in the law for foreigners.

verses.text: On the day the tabernacle was set up, the cloud covered the tabernacle, that is, the tent of the testimony. And in the evening it was over the tabernacle appearing as fire until morning.
verses.comment: The cloud’s appearance is described.

verses.text: So it was always: the cloud covered it by day, and the appearance of fire by night.
verses.comment: God’s presence manifests as cloud and fire.

verses.text: Whenever the cloud lifted from above the tent, the people of Israel set out; and wherever the cloud settled, there the people of Israel pitched their tents.
verses.comment: The cloud guided Israel’s journeys.

verses.text: At the command of the LORD the people of Israel set out, and at the command of the LORD they camped. As long as the cloud remained over the tabernacle, they stayed in camp.
verses.comment: Israel’s movements strictly followed God’s direction.

verses.text: Even when the cloud stayed over the tabernacle many days, the people of Israel kept the charge of the LORD and did not set out.
verses.comment: Israel waited as long as God commanded.

verses.text: Sometimes the cloud stayed only a few days over the tabernacle, and at the LORD’s command they camped, and at the LORD’s command they set out.
verses.comment: God's timings varied, but were always obeyed.

verses.text: Sometimes the cloud remained only from evening until morning, and when the cloud lifted in the morning, they set out. Whether by day or by night, whenever the cloud lifted, they set out.
verses.comment: Israel’s readiness to move at short notice.

verses.text: Whether the cloud remained over the tabernacle two days, a month, or a year, the Israelites stayed in camp and did not set out; but when it lifted, they set out.
verses.comment: Long or short stays depended solely on God.

verses.text: At the command of the LORD they camped, and at the command of the LORD they set out. They kept the charge of the LORD, at the command of the LORD by Moses.
verses.comment: Final summary of Israel’s obedience and Moses’ role.
